So couldn't the pupils dilating be a sign of our physical nature increasing the performance of a specific(or multiple) sense(s) of our body to be able to respond or react to the situation or task at hand. Similar to adrenaline being pumped at specific times vs all throughout the day.  In this scenario, the pupils dilating seems that the brain believes better eye sight is needed to help the body focus on the target (numbers in front). Probably to be able to intake information more accurately via visual stimulus.  It is similar to when we are driving, when we are trying to read a map, road signs, back up, or figure out which direction to go...we often turn down the radio...not that sound has anything to do with driving, but because we are instinctively eliminating a sense (sound) that is not needed in the calculation of direction enabling greater focus on sight for better perception/spatial recognition.  Modernize the times and add GPS or a navigator (think rally) and now you're including audio but only for specific cues like 'left', 'right', 'bear left', etc. so more of the senses are being used to perform the tasks.  I would attribute the pupils dilating to that of say a limited slip differential or perhaps a 4 wheel drive car with independent power for each wheel.  As you adjust one sense, or wheel in the example, it adjusts all the others. If you increase one, then you decrease the others...which makes sense because if you are in intense focus/thought, you can be oblivious to your surroundings, like tunnel vision.

1- figuring out how to do the thing slowly and pretty badly using System 2

4- system 1 takes over and it becomes easy and part of your comfort zone.

Thus, a lot of times, we were required to take fast decisions.

And this is what we call the subconscious mind!

Been thinking about this ‘cause every time I go do something new, I despise it. Learning a new art program, for example, is uncomfortable. I get mad when it doesn’t do what I need it to in the way I’m used to. I’m angry and frustrated and sometimes feel like I’m 3 seconds from giving up… but if I get past that, the result is worth it. It’s the “musician playing the same old song,” thing. He plays the same song so well, but he struggles with the new one. If he gives up due to the struggle, well… the learning stops.

I think it’s good to remember that we always struggled at the start of anything, even typing on a keyboard or speaking our native language. The fact that we got to the point we’re at is enough proof to tell us that we CAN get past the frustrating part and achieve comfortability if we are willing to put in the work. 🙂

So… I guess it’s time to engage “Drew,” whether it’s frustrating as hell for a while or not.

Eh, I have disability due to severe mental illness that means (in part) I can't think around people. I basically day-dream and rely entirely on automatic talking. Which maybe doesn't sound so different from most people but it's the only kind of social interaction (in person) I can do, and it's a painful experience anyway so I spend most of my time alone.

Fortunately if someone on the street approached and asked to ask some science questions, I'd automatically say no thanks and walk away. :p So you wouldn't know how dumb I am around people. 😎

Unfortunately it can cause serious problems that leave me at a disadvantage, like when trying to be the perfect parent social services want me to be. Yeah... mainly I talk about disability when it comes up, after they've told me to stop doing it. They don't like that.

It's also painfully stressful to be productive in any way.
I'm a fast learner, I learnt that when I started on strong meds, and they started working. Unfortunately they didn't stop the constant decline. But they allowed me to see who I am. Someone who loves maths, programming, physics. And is actually good at it.
And I can't do anything with it. I can't study, or work. That's the part that I hate. More than anything else. That's the part that makes me feel trapped in my mind (in a prison that slowly gets smaller). I can't even follow my hobbies.

I should clarify though. Although I do still hate that. And when I remember my situation it hurts. But I have a wonderful wife. Not in the same country for now but of course I have spent time with her. We're happy. I'm happy.
Anyway rambled on a bit here, just the stuff in my mind that flowed from the start of this comment. I'm gonna stop myself rambling more, it's a pointless youtube comment. :p

Oh, I will say: to anyone with a functioning brain unlike mine - be happy you can use it! Be happy you can push yourself harder and harder to reach higher places, whether it's in science or just something less scientific that you enjoy pursuing. Don't take it for granted. You're alive. There are a lot of unalive people who would really wish they could be in your place, if only they were alive enough to have wishes. :p But then they wouldn't need to wish to be alive... 🤔

Part of what you've demonstrated at the start of the video is not "not thinking" - it is being unwilling to verify it, which is most likely because of classroom or other life experiences where you were explicitly or implicitly taught that doing so is wrong. For example, a teacher tells you to answer a math question, but won't let you write it down or use a calculator "because you should be able to do it in your head." This lays the foundation for the fear of fact-checking, and also demeans people who, for whatever reason, struggle with that particular question, that topic, or have general problems figuring out things in their head. Otherwise, it was a great video.
It's terrible that how our automatic perceptions can play such a huge role in our successes at things.

In college (1980s), I was tested for the ability to remember random numbers. Result: 100% to 15 digits. The researcher couldn't believe it, so she repeated the test 3 days later, then a week later, both with similar results: 16 digits, and 18 digits, respectively. Apparently, there exists some improvement due to learned memory optimization.

OH MY GOD! Is this why my whole life I always think things twice? Once instantly and then once at the "speed of life".  A lot of the time they're the same; like this sentence. But I am consciously aware that I already thought it all out once and then I have to slowly go over it again because I can't even speak fast enough for the first one let alone type it.

While I don't think that the idea of the two systems is wrong, I feel like it's just another incredibly limiting overly simplified concept. To really get to the core of thinking you have to go back to your days as a baby, when you had no idea what humans are and that the concept of language exists.

If that process during our first years in existence is working the same way as the two systems operate, then that means that we first make a gigantic effort to bring order into the chaos on a scale that is never again repeated within the rest of our lifetime. This is why Gunn, if left unchecked, will eventually dominate Drew almost to the point of pathological mind manipulation, and not just in terms of "remember to lock the door", but more in terms of "do you even need to lock the door? what if the concept of locked doors make no sense in the first place, because most of us aren't using sophisticated enough locks to actually keep people that want to get in out? what if most locks only exist for the sole purpose of a fake sense of security?"

Not questioning the axioms/pillars of our existence reaches far deeper than these ideas make it seem, as Gunn is capable of picking up on the idea that there are conscious and unconscious processes, but can't allow anything that reaches too far into the depths of the base pillars of childhood, like for example the concept of plurality, where there's not just one consciousness, but instead several interacting with each other on different layers of the mind. What about the differences of visual and audio simulation? If Drew has to think really hard to simulate all of the complex overtones that occur in natural thunder, then of course, to think of a thunder sound, Gunn would always suggest instead just mimicing a voice that goes 'Kra-Ka-Koom' instead, which in turn will over time keep Drew from ever trying if he would actually be capable of simulating all of the complex overtones of the natural sound, for example by repeatedly listening to an actual audio sample and then trying to consciously simulate it back in his head.

Basically, leaving Gunn unchecked can very quickly lead to a collective misunderstanding of the true limitations of the human brain, as we will only make use of the things needed to function within set parameters that are based on axioms/pillars created hundreds of years before psychology even started asking questions.

3 kinds of thinking 1) Plain Jane retrieval of memorized information like multiplication table or recognizing a face or voice
2) Deductive logic or stepwise or logically deriving the consequences(implications) from an assumed hypothesis (belief). Meaning "If this is true then what follows"? Not always easy. All math and science, Euclidean geometry etc. involves this. For example. If light speed is a constant (principle) then find logically its effect (consequence) on time and length. Not easy but can be done one step at a time or logically. The ball and bat question was another example using a simple equation
3) Finally coming up with a Good New Idea or hypothesis (GNI). Most think this involves logical or stepwise thinking but it does NOT, otherwise all the GNI would have been discovered by now. Its an inspired or lucky guess or accident, like winning a lottery. One may get one or never get one. No guarantees. More attempts are akin to buying more lottery tickets. Improves chances but no guarantees. And very few amongst us ever get a GNI. Even Einstein, Newton and Galileo only had just a couple of GNI each.

This is really quite something doing something consciously and doing something subconsciously. When I first became consciously aware of countersteering, in my case on a motorcycle, you do it consciously. You  push the right handle bar forward to go right, this knowledge is very useful when you need to make a sharp turn for example. But after a while I found out that in normal traffic when you ride through a flowing corner it works best to just forget about it,  just look far ahead, look where you wanna go and then the corner actually flows much smoother, only when I am about to run off the road in a corner I then consciously push the handle bar, It's a funny thing the interaction between conscious and subconscious thought processes.

Ah, you're simply wrong, Supposedly Smart Guy.
It is not THINKING that is uncomfortable, while admittedly some types of thinking are uncomfortable sometimes in some conditions, the entirety of thinking is not entirely uncomfortable. It is that certain types of thought that are uncomfortable to some people sometimes under some conditions. Whether they are any good at it or not, is a different question. Amazingly you have fallen into the very same trap...because for you it is far more comfortable for you to think negatively than positively. You prefer to sow doubt, to undermine assumptions, to be critical, to destroy confidence rather than increase confidence. And so here now you have trapped yourself with the very concept of thought itself. So what do you do, naturally? You turn that high-power brain of yours into a self-destruct mechanism and indeed, attempt to immolate the entire human race right along with yourself. You prefer to have nihilistic thoughts. You are far from the only person like that. But you are also far from exemplary of humanity as a whole.

What you should have done with this idea was to continue to sample the population until you were able to ask a range of questions to create a mental space in which you could objectively sample the population with those same questions, and then be able to calculate the likelihood of correct answers based on the answers to the setup questions. You always start with something truly simple, easy, even obvious.

How much time does it take for the earth to revolve around the sun?
Sure. Easy. Obviously not easy enough!

These questions have to require near-zero thought. Because some people are just that stupid, lazy and thoughtless.

...and as for you, it's obviously logical thought that is uncomfortable for you.

You keep raising doubts and undermining common scientific assumptions because you hate to think logically.
You'd much rather think illogically and combine your illogic with a hot-button scientific topic.
You prefer to think of the absence of logic than the presence of logic.

For you, the fact that such answers to such questions are wrong is easy for you to see, because you PREFER to think about errors in logic, discrepancies between "known facts" and "truth". For the people who gave you such answers, probably the opposite.
"Earth revolves around the sun in a day? Yeah, sounds right to me".

And there you go.
You're happy, they're slightly less than happy, but only because they barely care about being wrong about astronomy.

Let's say,
Ball price = X
So, bat price = 110 - X (1 dollar = 100 cents).
According to the problem,
110 - X - X = 100
Or, -2X + 110 = 100
Or, -2X = 100 - 110
Or, 2X = 110 - 100
Or, 2X = 10
Or, X = 5
Ball price = 5 cents.

I used to be a superb student. I got into UC Berkeley and was in my last semester before graduating when I had a psychotic break. I was later diagnosed paranoid schizophrenic, but was unable to return to university once I stabilized because they wanted me to pay back my loans for that semester before I could return.  Of course a non graduate wouldn't be able to save $6,000 that fast. It would have been difficult even for a graduate to get a job that helped him earn that much in a short period of time. So here I am 8 years later finally almost ready to return, both financially and mentally, but I find that my mind has certainly grown lazier. But there is something within me that longs to learn again. I used to be good at it. There's a certain flow to it.  Working in bars and restaurants was stimulating at first, because I was never that good with people, so learning to get along with others took a lot of effort. Now, however, I once again long for stimulating mental activity.  More than dish washing or serving drinks at a bar can afford.  I hope my mind isn't too old to grasp new information any more.  I really want to make it through university and put this part of my life behind me.

I find that I am somewhat rare in that I enjoy being alone with my thoughts. I believe it has to do with the fact that I grew up before technology, I did not have a cellphone in high school, and I was also a social outcast. Every day in High School I snuck off campus to be alone, I spent as much time alone as possible.

The result was that I was very comfortable in my own mind. I loved to think. When I got away to be alone it was always just to walk through the woods, never to do some addiction type task meant to distract me (like league of legends or using my phone.)

Lately I have gotten caught by the addiction stuff, and I use it to distract myself. But i have been experimenting with ridding myself of it ever since I got sober from all substances. Without substance addictions my electronic addictions suddenly stand out prominently as being exactly the same as my substance addictions. I tried avoiding porn and jerking off for 90 days straight.

I tried not using my phone for an entire week. During both of those times what I found was that I was able to slip back into that comfortable mental area that I owned when I was younger. There was always an early adjustment period, that transition from distraction to being truly in my mind again was painful, but once in it it is so much better.

System one and system two seem misleading oversimplified models to me. I think the brain is more like layers of multiple systems each one working to process information within the context defined by lower layers. And information is only passed on to higher layers only if it is not recognized by lower layers. Otherwise, lower layers would just go straight to acting on the information without higher layers even knowing about them.

This is a strange concept because I find myself addicted to thinking, meaning it takes up so much of my spare time that it overlaps into some of my life - time that need to use to eat, sleep, work, shop, and so on. I assume I get some kind of endorphine hit by thinking. And I don’t mean watching smart YouTube videos like this, I mean staring at a blank wall and dissecting new thoughts and ideas to try and draw out their ultimate conclusions.
This idea that people are intellectually lazy is kind of the nail in the coffin for my hope for humanity, in the long term.
This follows from having observed different people every day walk into the same health clinic where I have an appointment and watching exactly the same lazy behaviour from every single one of them.
They press the button and wait for the front door to open rather than open it themselves. Then take the elevator up two flights, press another automatic door button for the clinic. Then they ignore the instructions to wash hands and wait for someone to arrive, just walk up to the buzzer on the other side of the waiting room and press it, then plonk themselves straight down in a chair obviously aware that no one is going to respond to the buzzer, and drown themselves in their mobile phones until their turn arrives.
The nurse today told me she no longer drives her daughter to school because of gas prices, so she had to start taking her regularly scheduled school bus. So she had basically been taking an hour of her day to train her kid to expect the privilege of being served for no reason other than laziness.
Laziness also explains the growth of meal delivery services, supposedly ‘free’ except they exist by preying on the desperation of underemployed ‘gig workers’, and cause the cost of food to rise for everybody, whether they order delivery or not. It’s the middle class exploiting the lower class to sustain their lazy privilege.
And in the next breath you can bet many will complain about high food prices, and about the wealthy exploiting the rest us.
We are doomed, as a society. That’s my ultimate conclusion.

In two years time, I went from being hardstuck Platinum in league of legends during all 4 years of high school to reaching Masters during Covid in College. The biggest change I did was constantly studying, processing the information, and practicing everything taught every singular day until it was second nature instead of playing the game on autopilot. The other incredibly important shift was watching myself and having a clear-headed mental and learning to be less toxic and tilt less.

I had more motivation to play the game than study for school, so I remember everything for the game than I do most of the topics I learned in school at the time. In your example, I forced 'Drew' to go through everything for LoL every day until 'Gun' could process that information much quicker and have it memorized as if I was just going through daily life. School, on the other hand, I do not remember as much of what I learned but I remember the process for applications depending on the class(Mostly engineering).

At the current moment, I am trying to do the exact same with Valorant because LoL has become unenjoyable and unbalanced. I'm going through many of the same learning difficulties in Valorant that I did for LoL, but it has been much easier because I have already gone through the process of becoming recognizably skilled on a completely different game: League and Osu. It would have been much easier if I was better at an FPS genre game and transferred the skills because the genre of the game is the same; instead, I have to go through the entire learning curve again because MOBAs, FPSs, and a Rhythm game are very different categories but some skills have been able to translate helping my understanding and differences.

Bat = X, Ball = Y
X and Y cost $1.10
1.10 = X + Y
Rearranged
Y = 1.10 - X
X = 1.10 - Y

X costs $1 more than Y
X = 1.00 + Y
Rearranged
Y = X - 1.00

How much does Y cost?
Substitution
Y = X - 1.00 = (1.10 - Y) - 1.00
Y = 0.10 - Y
2Y = 0.10
Y = 0.10 / 2
Y = 0.05
Ball = $0.05

Thinking fast and slow

The bat and ball question seems like a matter of interpretation, or in other words it's a question designed to be easily misinterpreted. The question is designed to make them think you are telling them the bat is $1 when in reality you are telling them the bat costs $1 extra on top of whatever the ball already costs, and both can be correct interpretations depending on how you interpret the word 'than' as 'than' can be either a comparison or an exception. I dislike questions like this, especially in a language like English where it is already easy to misinterpret what's being conveyed.

The five machine, five minutes to make five widgets can also be misinterpreted. You could interpret it as either each machine takes 5 minutes to make 1 widget, or you have five machines and each machine can make 5 widgets in 5 minutes, and even that it takes 5 machines working together 5 minutes to make 5 widgets. with the first interpretation being the more literal interpretation and I assume the correct one.

The third question is the only clearly worded question out of the three, It has enough information to actually tell what it's trying to convey.

What I'm getting at with this is misinterpreting the top 2 questions isn't a matter of not thinking enough, you could arrive at the correct interpretation and overthink to the point you end up at the other interpretations, it's that a question cannot be correctly interpreted without enough information because a lack of information makes you try to fill in the gaps and that leaves it up to your personal interpretation which could be completely different from the one that was being conveyed. As the saying goes, "I'm not a mind reader."

I’m a district manager for Jamba and in many of my stores we used to have the recipes for smoothies posted throughout the store. After learning that having the recipes everywhere made learning the recipes slower (since everyone would just revert to the recipe display instead of trying to recall what’s in the recipe), I removed all recipe displays but one at the end of the smoothie assembly so they can instead just verify, instead of rely on the displays. Since doing that our speed has doubled and when old employees return from school or other jobs to work for us again, they actually remember most of the recipes too.

The bat and ball question is intentionally deceiving and worded incorrectly and vaguely. He already tells us the cost of the bat. He says it costs a dollar more. In literally all math problems, this would mean what it sounds like, $1 full stop. By being vague with "a dollar more" and not meaning just 1 dollar, it could be that the ball costs 7 cents and the bat costs 1.03. Because 1.05 isn't just a dollar more, it's 1.05 more.
So the question is worded in a misleading way that could technically have up to 11 answers:
1.00 and 10 cents
1.01 and 9 cents
1.02 and 8 cents
1.03 and 7 cents
1.04 and 6 cents
1.05 and 5 cents
1.06 and 4 cents
1.07 and 3 cents
1.08 and 2 cents
1.09 and 1 cent
1.10 and 0 cents.
So people who gave the first thing that came to their mind (quick math, that follows what is said), don't feel bad. It's a trick question that is worded vaguely on purpose. In all other instances, saying "a dollar more" means one dollar more, because the word, "A" means one. A helicopter is one helicopter, not a 1.05 helicopters or 1.07 or 2. A helicopter more means one more helicopter, not a fraction of a helicopter. So it's not 1.05 necessarily because that would be more than "a dollar more".

If he wanted the answer to be solidly 1.05, he should have said "the bat costs its own price minus the ball, and is over 1 dollar", which would mean it would have to subtract evenly to get 1.10. Basically, it's a badly worded math question meant to trick you, by being wrong and intentionally vague.

i was just asked about a week ago to describe "being in the zone" when playing a videogame. without having ever watched this video i described it pretty close to what this video talks about. I beleive you can optimize your learning speed by conciously switching control to your subconcious once you have tried it conciously a couple of times. It helps to really imagine the information being written in a book, paper etc.. and being passed on to the subconcious. Then turn the concious way down and let the subconcious run trough what you just gave him.

Did you miss a note? dont even think about it IN THAT MOMENT. Keep playing, You can do a review of what you did wrong later on.
There is one exception though...Do you keep constantly missing THAT particular note? then stop right at your miss, think to yourself "WRONG" and slowly practice that particular part. This is somewhat common when learning to play an instrument, but i find it really helps your brain to speed up the learning process when you give yourself that "WRONG" or "CORRECT!!" mental feedbacl

Agree 1000%. Usually when I take notes on something someone is talking about, the act of extracting the important details and expressing them efficiently in terms of time and space is so effective that I never need to look at the notes again. Using it by explaining it to someone else or writing about it is even more helpful for retention. Obviously applying knowledge to problems is also highly effective.

This is probably why you can watch as many Stanford lectures as you want on YouTube without ever becoming a real expert. The important part of a university education is not the lectures (I mean, they help, but), it's the requirement that you put in the work to apply what you've been taught. That's why Stanford doesn't also release the problem sets and tests - then you wouldn't need to take on crippling, life-long debt to earn a piece of paper.

I remember I was five years old when my father taught me how to tie my shoes. No rhymes (I do not think such a rhyme exists in my mother language). No practicing, either, just the one time my father guided me through. Next day, I was in the kindergarden for the first time. And one lovely blond little girl asked me to do the back lace on her dress. I did without hesitation or mistake but never saw the little girl again (or, if I did, I could not recognise her --damned prosopagnosia!).

I feel like I use "Drew" more often and more eagerly than most, which means I'm more likely to get those little tricks right but it also means I overthink things a lot. As soon as someone asks me a question I go into: "you should think about this" mode. My girlfriend told me about a book she was reading about psychology and she asked me to questions, this was to prove a point about the human mind. The first question was: What's the capital of France? I thought for like ten seconds trying to figure out what the trick was, why she asked me this. I then answered: "Paris, but why did you ask me this?"
Then she asked me a math question like 26*13 or something, I didn't question that question because I just saw it a a math challenge and in a few seconds I gave the correct answer. The point of the questions was that there are these two different systems: one automatic and one thinking one, kinda what this video said, but I took longer thinking about the France one than the math one.

Repetition is not necessary the key to learning well, for Gun to be given responsibility to take full controls to perform effortlessly. Even to consider that there is a concept of repetition is not useful in learning, because no two moments are and never will be the same - there will always be something new to become aware that will be presented to the present person. It’s what we give attention to and how we get different perspectives of the desired, intended action, through genuine curiosity, because we understand the meaning and significance of knowing the information that will allow us to fully embody that knowledge, that will make a difference in the long run, IMO, because we know why we are learning for that specific purpose. A little example, regarding learning, from my recent personal experience (similar to Destin learning to ride the reverse bike and having problems riding a normal bike afterwards):
I've been living and doing research in Hungary now, since 2019. Before this, I lived in Germany.
When I used German desktops in Germany, I always switched to an English keyboard and used a physical English keyboard to type. I did the same with my office desktop in Hungary, all through 2019.
When the lockdown started in 2020, I had to start working from home, on my Hungarian laptop, with a Hungarian keyboard. The most common problem, for English typists, with German or Hungarian keyboards, is that the positions of 'Y' and 'Z' keys are reversed.
During the lockdown, unbeknownst to me, I got used to the reversed postions of those keys while constantly using my Hungarian keyboard. Now that the lockdown has been lifted and I've started going to the office again, I'm constantly struggling on the English keyboard - a keyboard setting that I've used all my life!!

This depends on the person, of course, but it is a weird kind of a thing. If thinking were truly uncomfortable, we wouldn't do it and we wouldn't have evolved from the apes that we came from, because one of the reasons we humans came to be was because of our adaptive tool-using to make us more pre-disposed towards the manipulation of objects than any other animal. We're not hairy because we wear clothes. We don't have claws or sharp fangs because we built clubs and spears. You get the idea. The issue isn't so much that thinking is uncomfortable, but rather effort is.

Consider: Nobody likes to work. No, you don't. A certain level of accomplishment may be fulfilling, but your endless is not fun. Working too hard to achieve a result is irritating. It means you're spending more of your time and energy on a thing you just want done. We use tools to do things faster because just by hand is long, hard, tedious, and possibly exhausting. Making better tools gets more work down for less of the effort, but alot of thought had to go into the invention of such things, and it wasn't just one breakthrough, but generally a long line of smaller breakthroughs just to get to your powerdrill.

To that end, thinking is really only hard because the problem is complex and a time-saving means to an answer was not readily available. I am well-educated and physically capable, but I am not against using a calculator or a wrench or something. In fact, my brain gave me the brilliant idea of how the problem can be solved easier than straining myself. Our brains are geared to find easy answers. We solve hard problems by making methods to solve them easier, and then it's easy for everyone.

I admit, it's a weird dichotomy, and it does breed laziness, but it doesn't make us hopeless or anything, so don't worry about it.

If the idea of communism is put through the system 2 part of the mind it would be found to be very flawed. But if a child is incapable of utilizing the system 2 part of the mind he or she can easily be fooled into believing it is a good idea.
This is happening now. And the soil for the implementation of communism began being prepared back with the “no child left behind” education system which shut down the exercise of system 2 thinking. Women have the propensity to utilize the system 1 type mind which is to memorize and regurgitate information. Men are lazy but do have a greater propensity to use the system 2 part of the mind.
This is probably because for millions of years women got pregnant by age 12 and remained in the safety of the cave or village with no source of new information and very few problems that required system 2 operation.
Men spent much of their time hunting and warding off danger which required much more system 2 problem solving operation. Dealing with the unknown elements in nature is totally different than nurturing babies in a cave waiting for food to be delivered.

This is a more sophisticated way of explaining my thought process during a emory experiment I participate din for university research. We were shown arrangements of coloured boxes on the screen and had to either recall the colour of one box the computer selected or we had to recall all the colour boxes in the pattern but we wouldn't be able to control what order we recalled the. Also one of the patterns would regularly recur and we could predictably be asked to remember every box even if the order of recall demanded was usually different. It did take up most of my working memory trying to memorise the recurring pattern at the expense of being able to remember the the more unpredictable patterns that followed it and you couldn't help but invest because you knew that eventually there would be a higher chance of recalling the entire set and being successful, when the following pattern could only ask you to recall one box and you wouldn't even know which one it was, so you could have been looking at the completely wrong part of the screen wasting a possible 'victory'. Eventually the recurring pattern got committed to longer term memory freeing up my working memory for the more randomised patterns but I feel like I was doing a form of chunking by remembering clusters of colours we already associate with eachother, such as RedGreenBlue or CyanMagentaYellowKey (black) sets. Other colours we're quite so memorable such as orange unless I could chunk them together with a complementary colour (blue) and suddenly the pair of them next to eachother was memorable.

I am switch-hitter or I use both left hand and right hands, but not equally. As a boy, my father would not permit using my left while working with him. So I'd use my right hand when working with him. My right hand developed to be stronger then my left hand. My left hand was used for writing, and eating. Sort of like my left hand was my female hand, and my right was my male hand.
I work as an electrician and my right hand became weak and painful to use, so I switched to my left hand. An interesting thing happened. As I worked with my left hand, my right hand became flustered with how slow the left hand was working. The right hand would try to grab the tool out of the left hand grasp without me telling my right hand to do it.
My right hand was making involuntary jerk toward my left hand. The jerks were small, but it was as though my right hand had a mind of its own. After a period of time my left hand enough developed skills, that my right hand could tolerate.

The problem with rationality is that It's virtually useless, to think hard, without knowing where and what to really hard about.  The wonderful thing about intuition is that it helps place you mentally where you need to be, without effort.  Some complex problems cannot be solved without intuiting your way towards an answer.  Rationality is best when it comes AFTER intuitions have made the necessary assumptions,  made relevant impressions, and created distant associations.  - that's when rationality is most valuable.  It's also valuable to be quick, not just deep in your rationalizations, because nobody can predict when and where to take 10 minutes staring at a pile of junk before something useful comes to mind.

This makes me think about concept of "baby steps" in learning. To actually learn anything, one must get Drew to work but if there's too much for Drew to handle, it becomes exhausting and objectionable. With baby steps you introduce tasks that Gun can mostly deal with by himself but only needs Drew for a single aspect of it while the rest is well chunked already in the Guns Library. This way Drew has enough working memory to deal with the task relatively easy.

I have a major pickle with replacing lectures in this particular manner. Some clarity is needed and I will elaborate:

When I'm actively trying to understand and learn something I need clarity. Sure, force me to reach it on my own. But at least I need resources with correct answers, with correct and consice explanations. Teachers make students do teamwork for a signle or a double lecture unit, provide no guidance because "well the point is to figure this out" and then quiz you on that next week. So I'm supposed to make Drew work almost as hard as the scientist who discovered the damn phenomenon, do it by next week, and for multiple subjects in multiple fields of studies. Oh but that's not regarded as homework time since it was supposed to be done withing the single or double lecture unit, homework is extra. That's just insane. And it irritates me to no end. Teachers do not have a clear idea of WHAT to make our Drew work hard for and how to guide us so we make good use of the time in class.

The time IN CLASS should not be used like this. This could be prep for class. "Try solving this without looking up xyz on the internet, you may work in teams" and then in class first half of the time is answering questions about it and second is filling in whatever knowledge there is to fill in, maybe diving into something deeper, accentuatig what is important and why. And THEN quiz me on it next week.

And you may say bUt sOmE StUdEnTs wOn'T Do iT well BINGO some will ALWAYS not do it, a system trying to appeal to the laziest while wasting the time of the plenty who aren't lazy is a sham for me. It's not fair.

Making Drew work hard in class =/= throwing us into the wild and wasting our time yet requiring that competency the next week, judging both quality/accuracy and speed. That's insane.

Nicely done video.
But I don't agree with two of your premises: 1) "thinking is uncomfortable" 2) "Drew is lazy". The mechanics preventing people from thinking about your questions are quite different from your assumption, because you're missing the fact of the "inner dialog" people's brains are continually involved with. This is a key factor.
While you're asking them your question, they'd actually have to drop their internal dialogue - which generally revolves around past experience and desired or feared future outcomes.

In order to give your question serious thought, they'd have to drop doing something their mind considers more relevant than your random question.
If you asked if they saw the grizzly bear in the bush right behind them, they might give you more of a mind-share, because self preservation will likely override internal deliberations of why Lucy didn't come to their house yesterday.

Either way, you are correct, that people are not too stupid to figure out good answers. But they are not 'too lazy' to figure it out either! Their "Drew" is just busy doing something else already.
If your question sounded important enough for them to want/need to know NOW, Drew would have to store the stuff he was thinking about, then reconsider the recording of the words you said, and so there will be quite a delay before they begin to process your question. In that time, "Gun" probably has offered up some "seems most likely" answer from a prefab stack.

Finally, I find deliberate THINKING to be very fun. But for that to work, you kinda need the ability to let thoughts go at will / avoid involuntary merry-go-rounds.

What good would this video be if I didn’t put forth the effort toward thinking about it? Here’s my analysis:

1.) This video supposes a dichotomy between “systems 1” and “systems 2.” (1:30). These systems inherently reflect the conscious mind and the subconscious mind.

My only input on this is, to me, a potential false dichotomy. Thus, excluding capacities as the emotional mind (fuel for thought), the shadow mind (where traumas/fear lay), the analytical mind (observational thinking), and the higher mind (where thoughts originate & where we derive meaning + higher education & philosophy).

2.) This video presupposes that we are the conscious mind, but not the subconscious mind.

1:44 - “you are drew”

I highly disagree that we can be one mind, but not the other. Instead I actually completely disagree that we are either. Instead, these are tools for our consciousness (awareness) to use. In the same way a piece of paper or a dry erase board is used. To believe we are the conscious mind is merely a materialist point of view. Simple breath-work and meditation will come to prove these concepts obsolete.

Anyway, thanks for helping me flex my prefrontal cortex, Veritasium.

Take those notions and apply them to how we think about.. the quality of our thinking itself. This applies to everything including our priorities and politics. But of course it includes a lot more than memory, and memory is actually no way to describe cognition. The video is sometimes conflating cognition with memory. Even in muscle memory, it's not the fact that memory is involved that is key, but what is being remembered. We are inappropriately fascinated with memory and data. Those concepts are meaningless. It's like saying it's important to have a place to store food. Well no it's even more important that food is edible and not poison.  It is not raw data that is in our memory that is the important part. It is the stored 'subroutine's of processing.  So the quality of memories and processing is what matters, not the concept of memory and data. The memory games are just not so relevant. Also in addition to 'subroutines'. we also store 'societal norms' that we are 'programmed' to believe in and adhere to, even if they are irrational and actually are bad for us all. But despite these comments the overall message in the video is still valuable. Thinking better does take more effort and also developing better 'stored subroutines' and even going back and checking on them and updating them takes even more effort. But our quality of thoughts is directly related to our quality of civilization. So our very survival may depend on our interest in thinking better, especially about things that determine the course of our culture and societies, like how we vote and what sort of improvements we think we need in our educational priorities. But really it's what we think about most everything that determines our civilization. Only things that are truly opinions make no difference. And that is a set of things much smaller than we currently and mistakenly normalized ourselves to believe. If you want to know if something is an opinion or not look at the consequences of having a different view. If you prefer soccer over baseball that has almost no consequence for us. If you prefer lawlessness or  'freedom to kill whoever you like' to having and enforcing laws, that has consequences for us and it's not an opinion that lawlessness is worse for us than some order. If you prefer to not being interested in our being accountable to reason, that has consequences, so it's not an opinion, it's factually a less desirable view. This quickly gets harder when there are consequences for both of two opposing or different views, but there are often ways of sorting that out too, ways that we generally don't care about learning or making important. The course of humanity over the centuries are the sum of us all over time. How much of an interest we each take in the quality of our views, the quality of everyone's views,  seems to be the most important thing there is. That implies not just that you look directly at views and try to sort them out, but that you look directly at what determines the quality of the process by which we form those views and quality with which you look at those views. Metacognition. It should be a whole field itself. Don't just think about things, more importantly seek to  learn how to think better about things.  You have to actively go and study how to think better, not what to think. And that area is not remotely prioritized the way it must be if we are to progress more and reverse some of the regression we are experiencing. We sometimes wonder if all intelligent life in the universe eventually destroys itself or falls due to poor priorities and not being prepared. We can't quite answer that question, but we can know that how much we prioritize the quality of our thinking and collective judgment determines how  prepared we are to protect ourselves from ourselves and other threats, and that it directly affects the quality of our lives and the lives of our future selves. It's the most important interest you can have.

Interestingly enough, as someone who can actually multitask, which is a very rare feat, processing different types of information at once, my brain has split into multiple people. I previously thought this was personas or alters like those who have DID but no, it's quicker, instantaneous. Imagine that Drew, being the first person in the house had a younger brother named Gun. Gun is a genius but sometimes gets too overwhelmed with all of the sensory input. Drew, being very smart tells a very anxious Gun, lets switch places. But instead of handing off the info, Drew allows gun to just make the decisions with confidence, without fear, without logic. He just processes. Now, when they switch back, Gun has no problem handling the work on his own.


Okay. Wunderbar. Now, imagine that Drew wants to learn 5 languages, be a cook, fashion designer, and an opera singer. Well, thinks Drew, that is just too much work for one person. It would take a village... It would take an efficient company. So Drew invites his mother, father, and siblings, and cousins to live with him and delegates one task to each. With every new skill, another family member is invited and so forth until there is an entire ecosystem of people living inside of Drew. This is not an illusion. They are not characters, they are not personas. They have evolved into sentient beings very much like AI. Or how our evolutionary processes work. Evolution in real time.

This video finally made me undestand why i hate driving.

I only drive very rarely, in fact, really only if there's no other way around it. And since driving is very complex and i'm not really used to it, "drew" tends to drive most of the time, which is pretty stressfull.
So one would think that it's best if i'd drive regularely so most of the thinking processes get into muscle-memory and "gun" can take over.
But the catch is, driving tends to be way more dangerous than people make it out to be. As we just saw though, "gun" tends to make more mistakes on the fly than "drew" which isn't necessary ideal in circumstances where one mistake can mean the difference between life and death. Therefore getting comfortable really isn't an option to me.


So that's why i'm currently stuck in a limbo, where i try to avoid driving all together so i never get comfortable. But if i do end up driving at times, it's tends to be the most stressfull feeling in the world, because i need to not get comfortable as well in order to stay safe.

I've actually noticed something similar to the light swtich example that happens to me.
Sometimes, If the first few times I do something, I make a mistake, then realize my mistake and correct it, THAT becomes part of the routine and is then a little harder to eliminate.
For example: When beginning a new semester at college, I had different classroms to go to. There was this building that had elevators, so once I get off the elevator on the correct floor, I would have to either turn right or left for my classroom, but in the beginning, since I didn't know where it was, I would have to guess. So I guess right, and then realize my mistake (because classrooms were in descending order and I was looking for 405 when the classrooms I was seeing were 406 and onwards), turn around and then proceed to my classroom. After repeating this the first three days, I would find myself making the same mistake over and over, and it became part of my routine, and it took conscious effort to avoid making the mistake. This happened especially when I was on my phone when walking to class.

I have ADHD, and the best way to understand what it's like is to imagine what it would be like if you couldn't regulate Gun and Drew.

When I get stuck hyperfocusing, Drew is using up all the resources possible, not caring if it's important or not. It's why ADHDers often seem to know a lot of random facts. Because we probably got stuck on Wikipedia reading the history of flags.

But sometimes Drew shuts off and Gun is left trying to process tasks that need attention. He tries to remember tasks and just can't, because it's not his job and Drew, who teaches Gun facts, is sleeping.

This example has made it a lot easier to explain what it's actually like, rather than what people think it's like, which is that I can't sit still very well.

Thanks for this example!

Actually I figured out on my own when I was a child that if you have two numbers that add up to a certain number, and that those numbers are a certain distance a part, that the bigger number is equal to half of the total plus half of the difference, and that smaller number is equal to half of the total minus half of the difference. I figured this out pretty easily on my own without talking to or being prompted by anybody else. It was simply logic really, because it was just a matter of the fact that the numbers had to be equally distributed about the average. And so half of the difference had to be above the average, and half of the difference had to below the average, so this bat and ball problem was something that easy and obvious for me to solve even has a child.

I was thinking about thinking, and I think that it's likely that evolution gave us the ability to think to get out of situations and learn to overcome them that way in the future it doesn't happen again and we know what to do. "Gun" in this case is what seems true and says, "okay, let's do this." After drew sees it, and says "okey dokie" the thought gets put into motion. Otherwise, it will evaluate the situation as much as possible before handing the directions to gun. That way at least something can be done to at least try to resolve the situation. If the situation fails, then one of three things happen.


Either it's a life and death situation and you die. Get out alive but now have analyze the situation again from what you remember that way if it happens again it will be to get out of. And if it isn't a life and death situation, then it will simply be that future tasks can be accomplished with less ease. If it isn't a problem right now, or isn't thought of as important right now, then drew will likely pass it off and not worry about it. If the thing does seem important, or seems new, then drew will take hold and try to see if he can solve the problem that way future situations can be resolved in less time and with less effort, that way it can be ensured that safety is more likely to happen.


Even if it's not a life threatening situation, maybe the brain sees it's value to seek an answer that way if it ever does need to be solved, it already has. But we forget those problems often because after a while we no longer see them as important since the time for it happening has not been early enough to view it as worthy enough to be remembered. For the people who like to solve puzzles or have a race to the answer, might like it because of the reward that comes after the work is done.

This feels very logical. Diagnosed with autism (ASS) this year, it seems my brain works the same way as anybody else's. I have a Drew, I have a Gun. It just feels like the personalities of Gun and Drew are more alike, sometimes even reversed. Drew is less lazy and takes on things that other people would leave to Gun, Gun is still the faster one, but Drew is a bit of a control freak and doesn't like the sloppy bits of Gun's work. (Which in the long run means Gun is even less accurate, because he doesn't enough practice and Drew becomes more and more 'right' about him). This makes me less prone to errors, makes me able to do things of the bat, that most people would struggle with, but makes me struggle with things nobody worries about and have a very hard time automating skills. I still struggle with things like left and right, but can easily swap them, which most people would struggle with. Also the example you gave of inverting the bike steering (which is easy to do if you cross your arms on the handlebars) made all of my friends fall, while I just adjusted mostly by favoring one hand and reducing the complexity of the problem. I thought that was the trick, but nobody seemed to get it, even when I explained how to do it. Now I am not so sure. It seems that things that are unconscious for most people are conscious processes for me, like body language. I too have unconscious processes, that are completely Gun's domain, like object-recognition, reading, language etc, but I'm much more aware of them than most people, which is why I like optical illusions. Since I observe my inner workings more than most, this shows me that my brain is actually better at some stuff, which is kind of reassuring if you feel inadequate and socially awkward all the time. The best description of what it feels like to have autism I found was: Alien planet syndrome. Like you are stuck on a planet where everything is illogical. Now I'm not claiming this is what autism is, especially since autism was all lumped together in ASS. But I am not suggesting this is what was used to be known as Asperger's feels like for everybody, it is just what it feels like for me. Maybe this helps someone, who struggles with being labeled with such a broad term, that has such negative associations for most people, like I did for a long time.
Back to your excellent video..
Observing myself it feels like there are more layers than just Drew and Gun. I think things like stereoscopic vision or non-logic interpretation and filtering of data are done by someone I'd call the Flash...(Since Gun is already superlative). He can hardly be seen, only by his results can he be known and can we figure out in which order he processes things. And underneath that, there is someone without a name, who can flood the system with emotions and can make decisions, like fight or flight mode, or the snake reflex, before even the Flash can move his feet. I see emotions as the Gas that Drew and Gun breathe. Sometimes these gases are a bit intoxicating, sometimes it's like there is Helium, nitrous oxide, in there or in the case of depression or mourning it feels like it's a heavy, sticky fluid. So this would be the part where my Drew tells me, that even though I liked the video and I gained some new insights from it, Drew feel it's dangerously sloppy and inaccurate as most metaphors are.. It seems to be something Gun would say and I get the urge to check. Great video!

Answers/Algebra for the Ball Bat Question


EQUATIONS GIVEN:
X = ball
Y = bat
Y = x+1


Plug in Y and Solve for X:
X + y = 1.10
X + (x +1) = 1.10
2x + 1 = 1.10
2x = 0.10
X = .05


Plug in X and Solve for Y:
Y = x+1

Y = .05 + 1

B=0.05

As a computer scientist, and IT professional, I find it disconcerting how technology is being used. People often thought a high-tech environment would be a smarter environment. But, as you pointed out in this video with the GPS navigator (a point I also often use to demonstrate the issue), the opposite effect is occurring. People are being dumbed-down by their dependency upon machines to remember everything, and do all of their thinking for them. This is already becoming apparent in Generation Y that grew up with connected devices. They show symptoms of not being capable of creative, critical thought, and are emotionally fragile from lack of interaction with other humans on a personal level rather than text on a screen. For employers, it has become necessary to augment hiring processes to weed out these broken people which is a considerable nuisance. Somehow, Generation Z is showing promise though.

For some of you guys...
So let's say that the ball is $0.10
And bat is $1.00.
But I only have $0.10 so to get the bat, I would really need $1.00 more to get the bat.
But, listen to this.
Say I didn't want the ball. Only needed a bat, since I already got a ball at home.
How much more money will I need to get bat if I have $0.10 with me in my pocket.
I would really need $0.90 more. (Cost is $0.90 more than the other item)
That was just an example.

So that's what he is saying that both total to $1.10 but
He needs to know how much ball cost since it is a $1.00 more.
So let's get rid of the $1.00. Now we are down to $0.10.

How many items are there? Only 2 items. So we must divide the remainder $0.10/2 to get difference between both the bat and ball. Which is $0.05.

Oh so that means ball cost $0.05 and bat would cost ($0.05 and $1.00 more).

Total for bat $1.05. Add them both. You get $1.10.

Let b represent the price of the ball. Therefore the price of the bat is b + 1

b(b + 1) = 1.10
2b + 1 = 1.10
2b = 0.10
b = 0.05

Therefore, the price of the ball is 0.05 dollars, or 5 cents.

The ball and bat problem isn't as easy as it seems to answer a unprepared stranger.?

Y is cost of bat (Y=X+1.00$)
Step 1) X+Y=1.10$
Step 2)X + (X+1.00$) =1.10$
Step 3) 2X = 1 .10$-1.00$
Step 4) X = 0.10$/2
Step 5) X =0.05$ , Y= 1.05$

SO the things that i learned in this video---
1. There are two characters in my brain, Gun and Drew
Gun-- (the unconscious , fast and automated one)..receives the sensory information , filters it, and sends it to Drew for performing logical operation like thinking, ,it stores the memory
Drew--( the conscious ,lazy ,and thinking one)...acts on the basis of information received by Gun , it uses the memory

2. Gun can hold lots of memory, but Drew can store only limited chunks of memory.,
When DRew works hard, body sweats, pupil dilate and heart beat rate increases,

3.It takes hard effort by Drew to store something into the long-term memory portion of Gun's library to make that thing automated and ,,modifying things in long-term memory takes time and effort(like opposite ways of switching lights),
Thus things get stored better if DRew works them out, that's why advertising firms nowadays use, confusing, billboard to make us think, and store that info into Gun's Library of experiences.

I know I'm watching a video and I'm doing so alone, so perhaps it would have been different in a different environment, but when I heard the bat and ball question my math brain flagged there was a problem with quick thinking and that I'd have to think it through... I think in person within a group I would be the one to say hold on, think about this. But then if my brain was racing or stunned by things my brain trips over (subjects of personal trauma) perhaps I would trip for the fastest answer... But as long as I am still willing to admit the cloggings of my brain, I would probably be thinking the problem through or waiting until my brain was clear to do so...

However there is a field I work in where I am giving an overall picture of some probabilities and statistics, to the point where a few percent difference in absolutely precise modelling isn't required, and in that arena I do employ some of the described shortcuts. I make as close a model as I can but as long as the general answer doesn't change, I give myself the freedom to ignore some finer details that could affect the precise answer, in order to get a simple but close enough answer. I still strive toward a correct answer but am always aware when there are variables at work that aren't being modelled but do not affect my answer dramatically enough to hunt down...

I completely disagree about the laziness factor. The real issue is information presentation and if you know you'll have to rework again all that badly presented information to fit a representation that you can process easily.
Not everyone enjoys classes where people talk, especially in math, it's one of the worst possible presentations and absolutely confusing and means nothing. Show it written and it's much clearer.

Due you nudge someone into agreement, or do you present it so that you have (and can!) draw your own conclusions? To stop people drawing "obvious" conclusions, it suffices to not present it in a standardized way. Writing it badly so that you pay attention is not enough, it matters to push to focus on the relevant parts.

That's what good teaching is all about, remove the clutter, present it in enough alternative way, but don't trivialize.
Require your students to do the same, i.e., present a topic from various perspectives and modalities (speech, graphical, visual, kinematic) and the understanding and skill will improve a lot.

That's also effort, but enjoyable effort, because you aren't stuck or blocked by someone forcing you to answer something on the spot, that is NOT presented in a way that is comprehensible (audio).

Thinking is not uncomfortable. A certain type of thinking where too many abstract concepts are mentioned, of which you don't remember the formulas is uncomfortable.

You require people to think in a way that is not natural, which is why it's unpleasant. If you showed that printed on paper, clearly, results would be much different.

This is mostly an exercise in remembering, disambiguating semi-understood concepts, and imagining something that is hard to imagine without pen an paper.

Again, thinking is NOT uncomfortable, it's quite enjoyable, if someone is not trying to put you on the spot.

I'm... uncomfortable with the conclusion. For the simple reason that most problems in life are NOT unique to you or your situation. At most they're novel compositions of existing problems that have been solved well countless times before – often at great effort and expenditure – by dead people (God bless dead people!). I believe we should delegate as much as possible to tools that help you automatically incorporate existing human knowledge, and expend mental effort strictly on not reinventing the wheel. At this point in the information age those tools still haven't taken hold, but it seems they're right around the corner. For example cramming a book of programming syntax advice into your head vs. having an IDE and linter contextually remind you of relevant knowledge. With the exception of real-time skills (such as martial arts) in most other fields you could make it with this type of live checklist hand-holding + a bit of well-organized foundational knowledge. I picked programming because oftentimes it's outside of the problem domain itself, accidental complexity ( xkcd.com/1629 )

So picking your battles is where it's at now. How do you sort out what belongs in your cortex from what can sit comfortably in your exocortex? He's a little trick to mess with your muscle memory.  We all know how to use a mouse right?  Well try this.  Your graphic settings somewhere should allow you to flip the screen. Do it.  Now at first moving the mouse is weird as it is all flipped around, but you can get used to it.  Now flip it back.  You can easily go back to moving the mouse the right way, buuuuut.  It feels weird.  You know you are doing it right but it feels off.  It doesn't last for long but it's fun to try.  The same can be achieved if you change your mouse speed settings.  Make it fast and use it this way for about 5-10mins, and then go back to normal. It will feel strange.

When I started learning computer science I've discovered how my brain works, and I'm sure other people's brains work the same way even though they might not be aware of it.
But basically I was hitting these "walls", where you feel like you're too stupid to understand something, think you'll never get this, and so on, that feeling of being uncomfortable basically. And what I've discovered through experience is that if you just sleep on it, the next day, things will start to click, and the more you repeat this process of forcing yourself to go through the material even though you don't understand it and feel lost, and then sleep on it, eventually everything will click, for me it was usually the next day in the morning. And all of the sudden from being completely lost and feeling stupid to feeling like you mastered the concept, and you can explain the concept to others as if you invented it in the first place.

So that's always my best advice for students, force yourself to go through the material and sleep.

comment_text:
Gun vs Drew is like Reading vs. Studying. There are many differences between Reading vs Studying. My definition of reading: you read the text, you understand the each word and rely on reflex a lot. Studying will be understand the fundamental concept of the statement. You will be able to answer all the question related to the statement.

Example 11:23 (watching video) is the example of some people will just read Derek's statement (Guy in the vid) rather than study his statement. How many people will question themselves in the head "what does he mean when he said sensation of understand?" "Why watching video give sensation of understand than learning? did i missed something?".

Other example, a simple text like "Lazy is wrong" most people understand it and practise it. But will failed to answer why it is wrong. Typical answer will be "Because you need to work", "you need to get a job" "because is not good" "because you need to take care of yourselves". If one would STUDY that statement, he/she will start to question the statement. Example the process of STUDYING will be .....what happen if one become lazy....mmmm...lets scale the population to smaller...let's say we only have 3 people in earth....HUMAN1: have a chicken farm & selling chicken as source of food. HUMAN2: Create clean and drinkable water. HUMAN3: Not doing anything: lazy. So now i have 3 human that consume but only 2 that produces. Consume > produce...which mean in a long-run food will get lesser and lesser. This is why they said, you need to work.
This is now just happening in educational video, it happened in school book too and everywhere, including a person's speech..."do not run with scissor" "do not curse" "respect your elders" "Go study, exam next week". How many of us STUDY these simple phrase WHY, WHAT IF, HOW, WHY NOT...

Not trying to say that everyone should use Drew than Gun. They both have their reason of existence. After you have learnt how to twist a door knob, it have become your reflect so you don't need to learn every time when you open a door or pronounce a word, using a keyboard. In our world we need some balance, some job required more Drew>Gun (creating new product, designing new ads, research) some jobs need more Gun>Drew (routine job, job that require more physical movement like wrapping a gift, operating a machine).

Gun vs Drew, is a story-telling way to let audience to have an imagination so that audience wont get bored. There are more to study how thinking work: how data turn into information, how reflex work. You know you're studying when you question it to its core.

The video is not trying to offend audience to watch it. But sort of like creating a path or gauge you, opening a topic. In order for you to use drew, you need to use it yourselves rather than given an instruction to use Drew. The journey of using Drew is very important, whether or not Drew's conclusion is right or wrong. Example how the apple fell on Newton and spark his Drew to think. Newton will not use Drew if apple did not fall. Just like any this video spark you to use Drew.

I’ve taken a LOT of undergraduate science courses (finished a BS in pre med, now doing another in aerospace engineering). The program forced me to learn physics from scratch (physics I). However, the course format is called an “active learning laboratory” and it has been FANTASTIC for the reasons this video covers.
There is a small lecture component, but then you’re tasked with applying the information immediately in a problem. The catch is that students are in groups of 3 in circular tables, so you’re forced to work every problem out loud. Together. Now you have to send every number, calculation, assumption, to your “Drew” so you can share it with others. You have to defend and debate with other students, so you learn the “right” answer AND all the common misconceptions, pitfalls, and fallacies that arise. The other engineering students are also very smart and it’s really cool to watch multiple minds overcome each other’s weaknesses to conquer a problem each night struggle with on their own.

So I will apply what I learned from this video. I am going to articulate whatever the key points were that I learned from this video into this comment. We see that thinking can be broadly divided into two systems of thinking, system 1 or gun and system 2 or drew. We can also see gun as intuition and drew as effortful, purposeful and deliberate processing. Gun breaks information into chunks and patterns of comprehension so that the processing is swift and we can act quickly. While at the same time, it is also much more prone. Drew on the other hand, deliberately finds reasoning, makes calculations and reaches a solution through steps. Drew is less prone to error. Drew's precision can be transferred on to gun for it's swiftness through practice. Solving problems and making conscious efforts in understanding these problems can help us to learn things in a manner that it might be ingrained into our knowledge system.

I don't think the light switch thing is that simple! You wouldn't actually end up switching the lights on or off incorrectly merely due to the directional difference, because what you would actually do is attempt to flip the switch to the direction it was already in, having no effect. For what you describe to happen, you would have to attempt to hit one part of the switch, have nothing happen, then slide to the other part and press it. Now, in my own home, I do sometimes accidentally turn the lights off on myself, or on when I mean to leave, if I previously left the lights in a state I normally don't. For example, if I left the bathroom light on by accident early in the day, and returned later, I might accidentally turn them off when entering -- even though there's no confusion about the direction of the switch. Instead, it's merely the act of flipping the light switch when entering or exiting that's familiar, and the fact that I'm not taking conscious account of the lights already being on or off when I do it. My point is that it's not the direction of the switch that's important, but rather the act of pressing it. If I put my hand up to the switch (because I left the light on earlier and forgot, or in your case because you had directional confusion in Australia) and nothing happens -- even if the lights are already in the state I want them -- I'm probably going to flick it the other way, and then get annoyed because I turned the lights off on myself!

Thank you Veritasium, He basically echoes exactly the same thing as those mystical traditions in which they convey that you have an aspect of yourself that is consciously processing reality for novelty or the present moment and information useful to you contained within it and a part of yourself that is unconscious and automated. We have all experienced this automation either by the passing of minutes whilst driving and wondering "where did the last few miles go" when we finally reactivate the conscious mind to wondering why we yelled or got angry at people we love yet when we consciously review it we regret the unconscious actions that were said and done in those compulsive moments. This is a concept that is thousands of years old yet still persists to this day, just modernized, to be honest it gives it even more merit. Mystical traditions suggest attempting to expend the majority of your effort focused on conscious observation of reality whilst observing what the unconscious mind is attempting to influence and then continuously bring about change in perspective as a result of this effort. The ultimate secret is that science postulates the existence of many more dimensions to reality via such theories as string theory, the consequence of these theories on us as beings sharing that same reality is that everything points to perspective being the way in which we navigate these new dimensions, we just have to push against  the (automation) inertia to do so. There's a part of yourself that is constantly informing you what needs to be done regardless of where you are situated in this life, don't get into that drunk drivers car, you need to quit drinking so heavily, your addicted to video games and need to pay attention to your significant other, start focusing on healthy eating, move to a quieter location where you can hear your conscious voice better. Once the initial burdens are overcome and we pay attention to this conscious part of ourselves we begin a journey that takes us on a path towards enlightenment, a path of perspective shifting that very few every decide to pursue. This path ultimately leads to encapsulating realities on a scale that are incomprehensible to most people, and i say this not with a smugness but with a calm knowing that the average person will not be able to relate to it.  The unconscious mind will attempt to explain where this leads but only the strong will resist the urge to take comfort in this false narrative. Our perspective is able to extend beyond anything you can imagine, those fighting the inertia will discover this and be lead to destinations outside the grasp of those not pursuing such perspectives and will ultimately find salvation, though i hesitate to use this term due to it's Christian influence but i am without another term to describe it's reality.

The study on hard-to-read fonts is "Overcoming Intuition: Metacognitive Difficulty Activates Analytic Reasoning" (Alter et. al, 2007). It is misrepresented here.

First, in that study, people solved the bat-and-ball problem more often in normal text (16/20) than in hard-to-read text (15/20). Second, as you can see from these numbers, the sample size was too small to draw meaningful conclusions.

See "Disfluent Fonts Don't Help People Solve Math Problems" (Meyer et. al., 2015) for the data quoted above, as well as a failed replication of the study. Hard-to-read fonts don't seem to improve accuracy at all on the Cognitive Reflection Task; the report underlying Derek's argument seems to be a statistical fluke due to a small sample.

I teach kids and use aps to teach mental math. When the students play they don't just dilate their pupils. Little wrinkles appear around their eyes, and their faces grow paler. They are also subject to attacks of frustration leading to various forms displacement activity. However, when they play normal computer games though they are much more relaxed and seem to be in a state of constant mild concentration.
On the math apps they can only last a short time and complain that their head hurts. On computer games they can play for hours. I explain that learning hurts and that is the same as when you train a muscle, it tries to persuade you to stop, and often exaggerates its distress - the brain is the same. One common thing about all the mammals is this tendency to exaggerate their emotions. Kids (and adults mostly as well) are the same and complain bitterly if you push them to their limits as if you were really hurting them. If you can get them over that though, they have get a buzz after accomplishing a difficult task and that can become an addiction> This is the foundation of many a great brain.
BTW the idea that muscle memory is all in the 'brain' is questionable and many researchers now believe that the muscles and various other organs do have their own memory without which many very complicated and rapid movements would be impossible.

I do believe some of "muscle memory" IS actually in the reflex loops and nerve clusters that are in and around the muscles. There are tactile and proprioceptive feedbacks in many learned muscular skills that occur too fast for the sensorimotor signals to be traveling all the way to brain and back. And, for instance, complete spinal injury patients can produce walking motions from spinal nerves alone, below their injury (not well-enough coordinated to balance or bear their weight, though). So it's more complicated than 'it's all happening in the brain'. The processing seems to be distributed throughout the network, with the brain handling what the lower nerves can't. And of course this makes sense when considering the gradual evolution from decentralized neural nets to nerve clusters to encephalization to true brains. All those systems are still there in us, doing the same work they've been doing for hundreds of millions of years.

I think there is a flaw in your assumption about why people don't think. Pertaining to your bat/baseball example I think there are two pairs of factors involved. One is simple expended effort for little to no reward. The other I think relates to the first in that we give ourselves a time limit to come up with answer that ultimately does nothing to benefit us at the particular moment when faced with that particular question. This is true for most people, except for those you revel in being right for the sake of it.

I think if you had proposed a reward for answering the question correctly and established a time limit for doing so I wonder how people would respond? How much effort would they put into actually solving the question?

Lastly I think the form of question plays role into how we approach the answer. The question is short and so our brains tend to look for the shortest route to an answer with which in this case seems to lead one to a binary choice rather than computational thought.

I believe the educational psychological reason for Drew's laziness is that we obtain knowledge in two ways: Assimilation, and accommodation. Assimilation of new information is easy because it connects to something we already know in a way that makes sense, but accommodation requires effort (Drew) because it is new information that does not fit any prior knowledge we have in a way that makes sense to us. When this happens it throws is in a state of disequilibrium, which we experience as something uncomfortable, so we try to fix it. The trick is to try and get Drew to work and avoid incorrectly assimilating information, or disregarding it (cognitive dissonance).
