I've tested people around and it checks out! We are really too lazy to think! Our minds seem to have a preferred format for new data and problem solving! If data is not in the right format that we can easily store, work on or contemplate, we need to process and format it! So we kind of like to have these picture cards format data. There's indeed a reason for this laziness, and I think, besides, what 2veritasium 'how to teach science' mentions, is collective knowledge! We gain knowledge that has been "chewed" out for generations, so they should be in the right format. Basic information should be acquired quickly so we can chew on new information. that is collecting, organizing processing and formatting in a way it can be transmitted and stored.
In my personal experience, my mind isn't powerful, so when I try to solve intense problems or chew them in various cycles(that may include visualize and simulate something like a piece of hardware), my brain stops certain functions to focus on that process! Many times, I go to sleep mode or sleep walk mode! Many times I'm unable to sleep when 'drew' decides to chew a little longer on a particular subject I'm worried or passionate about!
Now imagine you are in a dangerous situation and you need to solve a life saving riddle! You wont have time to sit and think about it, so, you gotta use what you have in stock! Also we'are motivated by success more than by failure, that's a good reason we stick to what we know very well!

I'm trying to wrap my head around the remark about watching videos that give "the sensation of understanding without actually learning anything". Because it's a thought has has crossed my mind before, I do know that learning things is a conscious thing and takes effort, and these videos always felt "too fun" to be educational. But then I came to the conclusion that learning something doesn't always have to incorporate hard work. I fondly remember some physics classes back in school which were interesting to me mostly on the basis that the teacher made it very easy and, dare I say, fun, to digest the information, going over topics at a slow pace and using a lot of real life examples and experiments. I want to say these "effortless" hours of learning were more valuable to me than, say, sitting over math questions after school to not bomb a test, employing a LOT of effort, really putting in work and understanding stuff and frankly, suffering. Because all of that math, I forgot about it again, if I had to guess I'd assume my brain knew full well I only had to know it for that short amount of time and that was it. But for the physics classes, those were memorable, enjoyable experiences - and I could still sketch up a graph and explain how a speaker works, or a doorbell and what have you, that stuff stuck to my mind. And even if it sounds cliché, I'd go even further and say that some of the things I learned in those physics classes inspired me deeply, giving me a level of insight into how our world works that did a great deal of shaping who I am today. Making me curious to find out more, at some point trying to pursue a carreer in a technical field (which didn't turn out to be what I wanted to do but hey, it was a try) and maybe, just maaaybe, that is part of the reason why I find myself watching Veritasium videos now.

I do understand this is entertainment first and foremost. And that the reason people watch it is primarily because of the excellent presentation, not because of a deepfounded interest in the subjects. And I do understand you, Derek Muller, literally made your PhD thesis over what good videos are (or are not) for teaching people. So you may well be the single most qualified guy ever to make that assessment. And still, it's like, I don't know, if I don't learn anything watching this video I want to challenge the notion of what learning means and how valuable it is in the first place, because at the end of the day these videos stick in my head and I'll tell people about it and they shape my views and make for interesting conversations and make me ponder and isn't that everything that matters? Even if in the end, all that remains is a "I've seen something about that in a video once" in a water cooler quip. If "learning" really just is remembering stuff I don't see why anyone would pursue that.

Actually, I find this pretty helpful. Think about how hard we're thinking when we're studying something new. No matter if it's a new language, algebra, new song on a guitar etc... The brain tricks us, it tricks us a lot.. The brains reward center is actually trying to fight against the whole learning process, making us procrastinate meaning: Doing something that gives us instant reward instead of doing something that would actually give us greater satisfaction in a future to come. Thinking is uncomfortable, learning is uncomfortable and the idiot inside our skulls is telling us to do something else, that rewards us faster. Oh geez... Then there's also cognitive dissonance, which is basically you have some information stored in your brain relating to some type of matter which is dear to you. Once new information comes pouring in which would actually change the way of your thinking about the same particular matter, the cognitive dissonance starts. It makes you feel uncomfortable and it's up to you: Do I accept this new information or do I go against it? Example: Flat-earthers still think the world is flat, even thou there's thousands upon thousands scientific facts and proven thesis's that say the earth is round... It also applies to media criticism, internet criticism and fact checking.. Take cognitive dissonance add thinking is uncomfortable add learning is uncomfortable and ask again, why people act the way they act? Why do we still have different opinions about climate change, history, religion, politics etc... It's a clusterpoop and I will always raise my hat and give my deepest respect for people who actually can process new information and change their way of thinking from wrong to right, since that is something that takes balls..

Hard to overstate the importance of what's being said here. As a gifted but attention deficit child, I could just breeze through everything on Gun and his huge library, without ever kicking Drew out of that chair, until I hit the point where Gun couldn't cut it anymore and Drew's hindquarter had reached a size where getting up would involve a hacksaw and a forklift, then everything fell apart.

You can't learn to learn, or learn deeply, or become an expert, or meaningfully create, if you don't get Drew moving to work the material in front of you. If you have the memory and the smarts, Gun can make you someone with near professional level knowledge and skills in a number of fields, but "near" is the distinction between being a true professional and being someone conversant in the field. The latter won't pay the bills, complete the projects, or in any other way contribute positively to your quality of life.

Do yourself a favor and force Drew to work for you, until he's used to it, and teach your kids to do the same, especially if Gun is working well for them. I certainly wish I'd seen this video 20 years ago, or that my parents had. Then maybe I wouldn't need meds to get Drew to even wake up.

The experiment with hard-to-read text failed to replicate. The original study had only 41 participants. The attempted replication had 7,000 participants, and found no difference between the two cases (easy-to-read versus hard-to-read). Andrew Gelman talks about this on his blog, but so that YouTube doesn't delete my comment, I will forebear from including a link. I would suggest googling "Andrew Gelman When are people gonna realize their studies are dead on arrival."

This video explains the common sense mechanic. People who often answer questions without thinking are lead to superficially understand things (the understanding sense, confirmation bias). You can see that lefty people often act this way, especially teens and youngsters. They often swallow a comfortable explanation to deep problems because it "makes sense", thus leading to ignorance.

The problem with this new teaching method is that at least from my experience, professors/universities aren't making other changes necessary to take full advantage of them. For example, last semester I took a physics class that tried this teaching style of doing problem sets in the lecture and having video lectures at home. There were a number of problems with this though. First, the lectures still happened at really early in the morning when people are still too sleepy to really do a lot of thinking. Second, rather than having a small class size to have access to the professor for questions and guidance, we were still in a massive lecture hall with a few hundred students. I may as well have been doing homework at home because being at lecture didn't help at all. In fact, the way they set it up was even worse than just having us do homework because we worked in groups and were timed, so in practice most people still didn't think about the problems because social and time pressure forced people to just accept the answer of the fastest person in the group.

Perhaps strangely, I do enjoy the sensation of so-called "uncomfortable" thinking, and I seek it out wherever is may be.

For example I like watching magic shows and marveling how easy it was for the magician to fool me. I ask myself: What did he really do? What's trick? That's the sort of thing I like to think about.

Possibly what is really uncomfortable about so-called "uncomfortable" thinking is its failures. Often Drew fails after putting in the extra effort, and this can lead to people not wanting to engage their Drew's efforts when the result appears to be no better than Gun at getting the right answer.

If young thinkers could be made to seek out the unknown, or the uncertain, and still feel confident that their Drew will get the right answer even if they initially fail, then learning will be more fun.

Maybe the trick with young thinkers is to engage them with tasks that require their Drew, don't cause overloading, and then give their Drew both the time and the number of attempts appropriate to succeed in the task.

More mature thinkers are used to their Drew failing, but they understand that this means that their Drew just needs more time and more tries at getting the right answer. Mature thinkers are no longer afraid of or embarrassed about Drew's frequent failures.

From a programmer's perspective, I can see two distinct kinds of thinking; one of which I deeply enjoy, and the other I find is just annoying.
The former is problem solving - I love to solve problems algorithmically and see the algorithm working, and know that I designed it.
The latter is arithmetic - Anything the calculator can do for me is something I'd rather not. So even though mentally adding numbers is a pain, designing an algorithm allowing the computer to do it faster is exciting.

There are assumptions in this video that are unwarranted. For example, the assumption that the reason people let system 1 do the work instead of recruiting system 2 because system 2 is lazy. Given the experimental approach, an alternative explanation could be that the problem being presented is boring or irrelevant. Assuming that students don't like alternative instruction because it requires more work is also questionable. It's more likely to be that students don't feel as competent when introduced to new forms of instruction. After all, they've trained all their lives to play another kind of learning game.

I don't think you really meant saying watching videos doesn't make you learn anything, there is, of course, truth to that, however, learning through a lecturer is very similar to watching videos, and with the added benefit that you can review it at any time as many times as you want. Without practice that knowledge (from my experience) is hard to access. Nevertheless, I've noticed that when facing a problem relating to a topic I saw/learned a while back, the context triggers that memory back and gives me some idea as to what to do. Ideally, I think we should be knowledgeable about lots of things, have access to internet when in need to review, and practice the things you do most often to build "muscle memory" around it.

There's a trick to make Drew less lazy!!
When Gun gets confused by something new, Drew receives it, right? And we also know that when Drew repeats something again and again, it becomes automatic and Gun can now take care of it.
SO, check this new habit that you could teach Gun: if delegating to Drew becomes automatic, then "the amount of energy required by Drew to put himself into effort" shrinks!! Drew putting in some effort CAN be a reflex that you teach Gun, with enough repetition!
In other words, you have to get used to the act of going through new and more challenging things! Easier said than done of course

This video is personally relevant for my own job duties. After far too many years in the grocery business, I do recognize these reflex actions, things to say, ways to handle a situation, that I just do sometimes without thinking. Sometimes, it even means doing something the wrong way. This job requires so much situational awareness to quickly move through tasks, which can pile up really fast. But this morning, I was doing copies for a customer while in the middle of 3 other tasks and my "muscle memory" or "Gun" part of the brain, grabbed the originals from the top loader and put them into the blank paper feeder, totally by accident. I KILLED the customer's original copy ... I wasn't even thinking and didn't realize it until the copies came out. I spent the past 30 minutes trying to make up for a 3 copy mistake.

My take on this story in the context of autism and aspergers:
Gun has many tasks and many levels of operation (Gun being the guy in the video). There is very basic information processing going on the the brain and more complex before you get at the level of processing where Drew takes over. For autistic people, the most simple levels of processing, Guns job, is not being done very well as Gun doesn't have the same amount of resources to process the information which causes an overflow of info that Gun can't deal with. Gun passes this information to Drew which will process it to figure out the content but Drew gets easily exhausted.

However, more is going on. A more simple level of Gun's operation also passes information to a brother of Drew called Bryan who has the job of experiencing emotions and Gun definitely also doesn't filter the information for Bryan well which overloads Bryans emotional center and amplifies experiences.

During social interaction, Bryan is overloaded with info which dials its experience up way too high and Drew is overloaded with tasks to figure out what to do, which makes it difficult for Drew to find out what the hell is going on.

On an early age depending on the person, Drew discovers that by controlling its life, stimuli can be avoided or at least diminished to a degree where the load on itself and Bryan is sufficiently low. By making life predictable, Gun faces more familiar situations that he is able to handle better. However, because most of the information of Gun is social information, that particular briefcase overloads the easiest and thus, social interaction is the biggest part of life Drew wants to avoid in order to minimize the emotional burden.

However, due to the lack of social interaction, Gun doesn't get exposed to enough social situations to properly learn social behavior which limits its ability to function socially. This further intensifies the problem. From an early age, Gun isn't given the opportunity to practice.

Later in life, depending on the severity of Gun's inability to process information, Drew gets so much worked up that he becomes a mental body builder, able to handle so much information that he can slowly start to take over some of Guns workload and engage in more social interaction.

For the luckiest among us, given the right information and lessons, Drew can learn Bryan how to experience Guns information to produce positive emotions such as happiness and love which causes Bryan to tell Gun and Drew to engage in more social interaction so that it can experience happiness, and so that Gun and Drew both can become better at filtering social information to the point where Bryan is very satisfied with life and social interactions become pleasurable. After a sufficient amount of time, Drew trained the long term memory so that now, Gun delivers just enough of social information to Bryan in order to feel happy and Drew to have plenty of energy left to enjoy live. I understood this intellectually, but a year before I got to experience it, by really paying attention to how my mind is working. Had to practice vipassana meditation in order to train my perception, to observe better the patterns of thinking.

Active thinking takes effort, and people don't like that effort. That is why we stereotype. A stereotype is a short story that takes almost no effort to recall.

The example in the video is very good: 7102 - 4 we have to remember four digits - four chunks of info. But reversed, it's 1 chunk of info - the current year.

When you become aware of this "experience" you will catch yourself taking a shortcut more often than before. You will see how when people get new information, they want to add it to an existing story in their head, to categorize it, because otherwise working with that info, in raw, takes effort.

I think the real genius part of this video is that since he realized that people would have trouble remembering System 1 and System 2 he made us use characters (Gun and Drew) to remember them. This made it take more processing power to convert them from characters to brain functionalities and thus makes us remember them. System 2 would lazily forget what 1 and 2 meant in the context, but now that he set us up with names and personalities it now took root with more information that we already had chunks set up for in 1. This previous knowledge that we have set up in System 1 has to check with System 2 as we actively think about the video and this makes it a more memorable path since it has now been traveled in both directions.

Also Gun and Drew rhyme with 1 and 2 so that helps too, but you may not have noticed that. :P

First Step: Accept that these two systems might be the source for many problems and that effortful thinking is crucial for progress.
Second Step: Redefine "uncomfortable" for yourself by viewing thinking from another perspective. Problems not only seen as obstacles that block your way and hold you back but instead to see them as challenges to test what you know and see how far you can go with what you have.
Why?: Then uncomfortable thinking can be transformed. The plain wall of effort that you run into and that breaks you as well as your motivation can be transformed into to a wall with doorways of opportunities that you and anyone else can try to go through and even enjoy doing so.

*note: if you were to try that redefining it most certainly will be Drew to do that in the beginning, so it is effortful and time consuming. Just like everything else though it will become more and more the job of Gun and eventually a habit. A habit of being constructive.

The fact that thinking requires effort is part of what will be our undoing. It is at the heart of the fundamental flaw in civilization. Not just OUR civilization, but the concept of civilization itself. Civilization consists primarily of removing danger from peoples lives. That danger is precisely what motivates people in visceral, personal ways to defy their intuition (which drives them only to repeat the same tragedy endlessly) and dedicate themselves to the effort of thinking. So, then, civilization consists primarily of removing all tangible personal benefit to thinking.

We construct grand infrastructure (when I say 'we', I mean the thinkers among us, the intellectuals) which keeps people safe and makes them comfortable. We remove even the dangers which come as consequences of a persons own actions. We strive for the point where no thought is necessary to live without danger. As we approach that, however, we reach a tipping point. A point where following ones intuition, which is effortless, becomes what a society values. Where they can not see the benefit of expending the effort of thinking. Mis-steps in thinking of the past are fixated upon and seen as proof that thinking is malign, that it is deception. Intuition, after all, seeks to categorize all things with binary finality. A thing is either Good or it is Bad. Considering nuance takes effort, it takes thinking.

And as a number of people emerge who guide their lives through intuition rather than reason, they find themselves no worse for it. They begin to teach their way of living to their children. They look upon those who expend their energy on thinking with doubt, if not outright derision. When those people ask things of them, or expect things of them, they see no reason to cooperate. They stop vaccinating their children. They seek refuge from food with 'chemicals' in it. When it comes time to approve a tax levy to continue to fund research or expand the infrastructure which has protected them their entire life, they refuse as it seems a total waste to them, if not an active menace.

They can not be reasoned with. By definition, they reject reason and decide their beliefs based on trained Pavlovian conditioned responses (trained unintentionally and haphazardly by their life experiences and informed by nothing more). You can not reason someone into accepting reason. And if you batter or coerce them or manipulate them emotionally in order to relate to them in the way they prefer, you will have revealed yourself as a total hypocrite and your position will never be adopted. They will continue in their certainty that the infrastructure is unnecessary or that it holds them back from the natural paradise which they are sure life without it could be.

And so they seek to remove the infrastructure. You might think that as the danger re-asserts itself in the absence of the protective infrastructure that they would immediately realize their mistake. But this is not how the human brain works. This is not how intuition works. Intuition is what defines every fallacy of argument and thinking we have ever formulated. Intuition is ad hominem, is crude assumptions of causation from circumstantial correlation, etc. And when danger re-asserts itself, the 'Sunk Cost fallacy' comes to the fore. They will believe they have not gone far enough. With their child dead in their arms from a preventable disease due to not having them vaccinated, they will not realize that the entirety of their worldview is fundamentally wrong. They will blame some other remaining aspect of the infrastructure. And they will fight with twice as much vigor to have that other part removed, with a fire of passion that sways many who look for passion first in deciding what to believe.

So it will go, until humanity returns to their 'ground state', if you will. The state in which humanity existed for tens of thousands of years before the development and spread of rational thought as an intentional system of evaluating ideas and of deciding how to live and act. Slogging through mud, disfigured with the scars of disease, stumbling from famine to famine killing one another as tradition or over whose god is strongest.

This is the most significant problem facing the human species, in my opinion, and I see no ethical solution. (I say ethical because the only ideas I can come up with are stupendously dark and radically unethical) It seems fundamental in the definition of civilization and how the human brain works.

Is this an intentional reference? Nikolai Lobachevsky was one of those great scientists who was making real conscious effort to work on something that everyone else took for granted.

«William Kingdon Clifford called Lobachevsky the "Copernicus of Geometry" due to the revolutionary character of his work. <...> Before him, mathematicians were trying to deduce Euclid's fifth postulate from other axioms. Euclid's fifth is a rule in Euclidean geometry which states (in John Playfair's reformulation) that for any given line and point not on the line, there is one parallel line through the point not intersecting the line. Lobachevsky would instead develop a geometry in which the fifth postulate was not true».

What is the thing that driving people to be THIS curious? He was like «hm, they say there is only one possible line. Bah, can I make it infinite?»

@Veritasium I have a hypothesis on the pupil dilation phenomenon. When given a complex task the brain is trying to suppress all external stimulus to create a distraction free environment (so that it can divert all of its computational power to the task at hand). Visual stimulus takes the largest amount of computational power hence suppressing it makes the most sense. You can suppress it by either changing the focal point of your eyes so that you loose all detail in the incoming image or just by simply closing your eyes! The dilated pupils are just a response to out of focus eyes. IMO closing your eyes works better. What do you think about this?

I run into this with language learning. Knowledge training with a SRS flashcard program like Anki. Basic idea is break information into a 1 unit chunk (Kanji or Kana or a Word or a Phrase or a Grammar point, etc). Test immediate recall of each unit at longer and longer spacing to see if you really can remember the item ie Gun doing his job correctly. If you miss it, Drew takes over and sees what went wrong. Amazing system that works great with computers and networks.

I remember when I used to deliver pizza I would always use the gps. After a few weeks I noticed that there were a few houses of regular customers I would always go to. I figured by now I should have known the way to at least some of their houses but I was too afraid (being pushed for time on the job) of getting lost. Then one day I read an address that I had been to at least half a dozen times and I said f*ck it and just tried my best to get there without the GPS. During the drive I was unsure of the route as a whole but as I went passed individual familiar landmarks I somehow knew exactly where to go next. I think that "Drew" processed the gps phrases so much that "Gun" eventually just knew the route by heart. So not only did I make it to the address but I made it there quicker because I wasn't constantly looking at my gps for directions that I didn't even need (also it's a lot safer because I actually had my eyes on the road).

I think this is what religion is all about. It gives the feeling of understanding by handing out answers and claiming to be all knowing so that people don't have to invest the energy of being uncertain and second guessing themselves and authority figures. But sometimes people are wrong. Sometimes what has been believed for centuries turns out to be wrong. If no one ever goes outside of the 'handed down' knowledge, then no one will ever know. They will just react with preprogrammed behaviors. Isn't that just instinct? If all we have is instinct, then we're just dumb animals, not intelligent life forms. Right? At the same time, I'll just point out... it seems to me that instinct is what we are. If we don't attend to our instincts, then 1. our species will die out 2. we won't have any attachment or motivation. We won't know what to do with ourselves. So, I think the more evolved aspect of religion is that it attempts to replace our inherent instincts with a better version, an upgrade. The problem is, it might still be an old rusty version and either way still treats us as brutish beasts, not intelligent beings. And actually, that's not just religion, but that is what culture in general does. Until you can alienate yourself from some aspect of your culture and consider it in a detached manner, you can't really ever judge it and can't know what it's real value is. I honestly find thinking pleasant and it seems to be completely at odds with a lot of what is stated for a person that finds thinking unpleasant. The GPS example: I learned my way around a decently sized city entirely by working as a delivery driver relying on GPS. However I would constantly think about things based on what I seen in the area as a pleasant way to pass the time when I wasn't singing along to the radio. As a result I got to the point where I was able to not only find my way around the city, the sense of direction translated to my bike when I needed to pick up 100lbs of car parts, 10-15 miles away and wanted the shortest possible route with my phone GPS out of commission (couldn't afford to keep service active at the time). I found I was able to recall those maps from GPS as if I was recalling paper maps.

However I do have the advantage of having learned to read maps through mountain biking and a lifetime of gaming. Not everyone has that benefit.

Excellent video. Something important to add is that Drew is a limited resource, hence its "laziness". There is a finite number of times you can use it per day, and its efficiency will tend to decrease each use.
It is close to the phenomenon called "ego depletion", that leads to a decrease of sound decision making and self-control.
People who have used Drew heavily will show less capacity at resisting pain afterwards, for instance.
Physiologically, scientists link that to the decrease of glucose in the blood, the main "food" of the brain.

I Used To think, of ADHD as a bad thing, because everyone I cared about & trusted said it was, & it did make me, different from plain average. I would be studying one subject, & get distracted by thoughts about the individual pieces, of how the subject was explained to me. On average if someone is talking to you & they use a word new to your vocabulary, you'd book mark that word & look up it's meaning, ask them to discribe the word, or assume by deductions. I on the other hand, have never been able to save it for later, & I try to figure it out, while being distracted from information being offered. If I saw, something being discribed, more senses were needed, & I was able to recall pictures better, do to my dyslexia. That's how I read as well, & one reason I must read & re-read things. If I read out loud the quakieness of my voice is evident, & that's my mind struggling to stay focused on reading the words, & trying to think about what the words I'm reading really mean.
However this has also lead to connecting almost everything, being able to relate them to each other. So I can break things down to their origins. I see patterns, likes 6 degrees of separation. That's why I'm famous for using Analogies, to get my points across. However, the 'average person' doesn't think that way. They assume I'm getting off topic, or their train of thought gets sidetracked, much like my mind does trying to learn their way.

I don't think you got right why students don't like those formats. At least in my experience, is because they don't want to make mistakes when answering a question and look stupid in front of everyone. Extroverts always participate no matter what, but introverts will run away from that type of classes because they don't want to be the center of attention. Smaller classes (in number of students per class) or formats where you don't see the other students (like online courses) actually make everyone much more willing to participate. Don't take the easy way out of "oh, they just don't like thinking too much because they are lazy" like a snob, and actually care and analize the reason why people behave the way they do.

That's... incredible. Mainly because I realized that my Gunn has his own Gunn, but Gunn-Gunn(I'll call him Zylo) is lazy, doing a ton of thinking and just dumping ALL the information on Gunn. And because Gunn is such a Drew he then thinks about all of it extensively and filters the thoughts, only letting the ones that might be relevant out. All the while Drew is relaxed, cherrypicking easy to comment on information and saying these comments out loud.

What I'm saying is: There's two factors in lazyiness that amount to three layers of things getting done.
-Zylo, loves thinking of anything possibly relevant, to lazy to check it's actualy use
-Gunn, loves getting free information, but only because that gives him tons of ways to check for possible uses
-Drew, doesn't bother with information, focuses purely on detecting useful combinations

Example:
Drew thought 'during all this Gunn found tons of connections to how I work, but I need a name for that third aspect Gunn has been brainstorming about'
Zylo thought 'possible names can be anywhere, tech, information, storage, searching, whatever relevant, I'll send it to Gunn'
Gunn thought 'Zylo sounds techy, take it into "maybe" ' a bit later he thought 'and it rhymes with Silo, which is storage'
Drew thought 'that's fun, let's write this into the comment, oh, and let's add that whole explanation that Gunn came up with, too'

I'm actually very good, or bad, at this. If you present me with anything that requires cognitive reasoning, I will stop everything, I have what I call my "thinking pose", I look down and stop processing visual and auditory stimulation, I block everything out and solve what I was challenged with on my head. This is good because my friends think I'm some kind of genius, but it's terrible because it's very taxing on my brain, it's also why I love comdy shows, because I can just relax and focus on something out of my head. Sometimes I just propose challenges to myself and spend minutes at a time day dreaming about crazy scennarious. Plus, don't even get me started on math, every time someone proposes an equation I NEED to solve it in my head, I can't ignore it, in this video, for instance, when you asked yourself what was 13x17, I immediatelly had to pause the video and get the result before I kept going. That is something that I love and hate about my brain.

I've read a few things about controlled vs. automatic processing, and stuff has come up on my undergraduate course. While I accept the research, and it certainly matches my personal experience of how things work, the thing that bothers me about it is the 'ghost in the machine' that it implies. I need to read more about it, but the question is this: who is it that is supposedly controlling stuff, and what happens to him/her when we're on automatic? Which one is 'us'? If this question seems banal, then I've not communicated it properly: it's a non-trivial problem.
I'm not expecting an answer, and it's definitely not a criticism (I know your Gun/Drew thing is an analogy, and one that works. You've also really helped me out)... It's just a thought! :-)

I really can't say that I feel unpleasant when I am learning new things. For me the path to work out an answer, may it be correct or incorrect, is almost always really pleasant and rewarding for me. On the other hand I am studying the topic i was fascinated by all my life, technical engineering. For me it doesn't matter if I'm studying fluid dynamics or static engineering I almost always enjoy doing so. But I always need a target to learn by myself. I always think about a project to do to learn something. E.g. I want to learn something about aerostatic bearings so I decided to take apart a small engine and started to test how the crankshaft would behave if you use air as lubricant instead of oil. After I did the test I compared results and tried to lern what went well or wrong and tried to improve the testessembly after a few treys I had a working prototyp and a theory how an engine has to look like if you want to run it on air as lubricant. That's classic trial and error but it keeps the brain busy and is fun and you can write a wonderful classiest/exam or what not if you learn by practical experience rather than normal theoretical class practice. Of course no one needs to buy an engine to get the principals of the engine but you can hardly create what you never got your hands on. If you want to learn engineering engineer something. Don't get expensive stuff, try to repair e.g. A broken lawnmower or a toy car or a radio. Take it apart (pull the plug first) and try to find the error you can't brake things twice. Yes you can mess up but who cares it was already broken if you do. Just take the experience from it. Level your brain!

This video explains the entire political spectrum. We often "pick a side" and then rather than revisiting our decisions, we instead figure out which side is ours. "Gunn" will bring up justifications for our side, and "Drew" will avoid conflicting information. It's easier... Gunn files conflicting information under "Misguided opposition" and that's all the excuse that Drew needs to not think further. We have this innate ability to write off information we'd rather not think about. Drew isn't just lazy, he controls the garbage can. When Information requires thought, he can instruct Gunn to simply throw it away and devalue that information. Ironically, this is why many on the left see justification in blaming religion for the problems with education or abortion, but will see no irony in defending Islam from being called radical. Likewise the right can criticize immigration for a lack of jobs, but see no irony in lowering taxes of companies that hire foreign workers. Drew is very talented at short handing information. The chunks that help us remember stuff makes it so we can also assign quick values to information regardless of truth. When Obama said that women make 78% of what men make doing the same job. Many in my generation gave it value despite being a mischaracterization of the data. Given the "Same job" line, it was just simply not true. But those same people will criticize Trump for saying that he had a large crowd at his inauguration... despite the fact that the inauguration lie wasn't an attempt to pass legislation and had far less weight. It's probably Drew's worst quality, and something you have to consciously work to counter.

What's really impressive is how clear can Derek put up an explanation. Often you see youtubers of the same genre having trouble trying to explain some idea, they either seem rather vague or too complicated. But Dr. Mueller doesn't seem to have that difficulty. If you check his other videos you'll see the amount of "information poured" is always constant, meaning he never overloads "Drew", he also explains the same idea repeatedly but with other words/different format from the way he first presented it, meaning that he is repeating to get it to stick to your head(I think he even calibrate the background song to match the exact moment where he explained when he returns to the topic, settling it down in the same tune).
My professor used to tell me that in order to explain something to someone, you must resonate in the same brain wave as theirs, and a good teacher will play many "notes" of the same idea, just like a musician plays an harp. Marvelous... I think that the behavior of gun is related to the brain activity working as a feedforward network (much faster but only capable to recognize particular pretrained patterns) and drew with a recurrent network (much slower but capable to recognize new thinks).
I was aware this behavior in a neuro-scientific test were I was challenge to see an image of colored animals by a really short amount of time. The results was that me and the rest of the audience were able to recognize the animals, the present colors, but not the proper relation between colors and animals. e.g. I saw an elephant, a giraffe and a rhino, I saw red, green and yellow but I can't remember the color which corresponds to each animal .

Excellent video. I find Derek's breakdown incredibly inspiring. This stops "becoming an expert" from being such a vague term and makes you realize how that is actually achieved- down to the fundamental levels of biology and psychology. For any computer scientists who wants to read on, I visualize the same process as one would with a serial/parallel computer.

Drew and gun are like serial and parallel processor (right and left hemispheres). The parallel refers to the serial whenever it realizes it doesn't have an immediate answer and requires help. So the more the parallel side refers to the serial side, say about playing the piano for example, the synapses between the two sides grows stronger and the information is grouped as big ass neurons in the serial side. And because the synapses become stronger(myelin), information is able to transmit almost immediately between the two sides, and the parallel side is able to send information to the rest of our body and cause motion. That's how muscle memory in athletics, music, etc is formed. I find it really interesting because that's how like theoretical physicists or computer scientists are able to solve these foreign-ass impossible-looking equations- they just store the simpler ones in giant neurons in the serial and are able to refer to them and the underlying concepts automatically and build easily on top of that.

Learning to TIG weld was the most uncomfortable thing to learn, ever. Even though I love TIG welding.
When welding with TIG you have to take account the position of the electrode, the angle of it, the speed you move at, the position and angle of the filler rod and how much you feed. During all this you also have to keep an eye on the shape, size and position of the molten pool.

The only way I actually learned it was by focusing on learning one thing at a time, not the whole thing. Now I just need to focus on Torch's angle, Filler rods angle and the shape of the pool. Which is still a lot for me to focus on.

But why I love welding is that it zones me out, I need to focus so much that I just don't acknowledge anything around me. I don't think about the problems that bother me, my worries, there is only me and a pool of molten steel.

So explain to me why I have a great thirst for knowledge!

To quench such a thirst, one must do a gathering of information about what one wishes to know. That involves the process of thinking, and in turn learning. It is true that to learn one must think. Also to be able to think about a certain thing, information must be found about it, and we do that by asking questions and seeking answers to those questions. One cannot really learn effectively without asking questions. Questions serve one main purpose for the person or entity being asked; to identify what the one asking the question wants to know. And here is where the thinking comes in at the beginning of the learning process; thinking about how to word your question for maximum understanding of what it is that you wish to know. If you can do that, you are more likely to get an answer that tells you exactly what you want to know.

So learn how to compose great questions, so that the recipient of the question will be able to identify what you wish to learn. Also know this: "The only real stupid question is the one you never ask!"

That's pretty much the idea on what television games rely on most of the time, isn't it? Giving sometime "stupidly easy" question, but timing it so we can't really use our part of the brain that would figure it out. Plus, giving easy questions (with or without a twist) reinforce the feeling that our "automated" part of the brain can answer easily... To finally get it wrong and lose our gains, which profits the television show.
All of this while spectators think, like said at the start of the video, that they are much more smarter than the candidate, glorifying them in some way to make them keep watching the show (ie: "this show makes me think I'm smart, so I should keep watching it because it's a pleasant feeling.").
I'm also guessing that since the spectator is using his "lazy but effective" part of the brain to be "smarter" than the candidate, he's in a mindset which helps the advertisement compagnies in having our attention more effectively.

- Once every three weeks
- Every 28 hours
- Three times per year
- Every six months.

My personal favorite was, "None. That's a trick question, because the sun goes around the earth."

I know we shouldn't judge others based on their answers, but in this case, these are child educators. Shouldn't they have the answer to this under their belts already?

Thing is, if you're stopping people on the street, you're putting them under pressure to give a quick answer. It's not that they don't want to put the effort in to think about it, they're just anxious. Likewise with the counting to the beat test, tests always put people under pressure and performing tasks to a timer is also stressful. It's not that the effort of adding is causing you to breathe faster and your pupils to dilate, it's that the situation is stressful and these are natural stress responses. When you're put into a situation like that, you do what every other frightened animal does: literally anything other than thinking.

So how this pertains to teaching, it all depends on the kind of question and how it's asked. If I ask you, "Name the capital of Peru", there's a definite answer, it's a short answer delivered as if you should know it and I've put you on the spot to answer it right now. If you're relaxed, you might pause and mull your way through various capital cities and countries, narrowing down the possibilities. If you're in a class, you're being watched by two dozen other people and you don't have time, so you won't think about it, you'll blurt an answer out. To actually get people involved and using their brains, you've got to approach with an untargetted, open-ended question, so people start to think about what answer they could give, maybe even tell them specifically to pause for a moment and reflect on it. That's got to be more effective since you're putting people into their comfort zone while simultaneously getting them to think.

Consider when you do your best thinking. For me, it's absolutely always when I'm alone in my room, no pressure on me, just sating my curiosity and taking my time to consider various answers to a problem that has been issued as something with no clear conclusion. That's how a good classroom should feel: you've got time to think, there's no pointedly wrong answers, your reasoning is significant and maybe more interesting than your answer, so the focus is on the journey of thought and not so much the destination.

I think magistral education is useful and pretty great if it's done in the proper way, and on both sides. The orator should give out the basics pieces of information and insight(the insight part is the most important, especially on abstract subjects like math formulas and algorithms or information workflows), rather than spilling out facts and anecdotes. While the student should listen and be able to vulgarize or synthesize the information and write it down. This way you both have a first pass on the information that forces you to process it to some extent and lay the foundation for faster and better integration on the second pass as your read it.

But sadly world experts aren't always good teacher, since they see most insight as acquired and too obvious to transmit, so they stick to faster transmission by only giving out facts...( but that's from my MOOC experience, real university education in a smaller establishment provide the proper magistral setting for insight transmission and proper learning.)

How can things in a lecture exceed drew's capacity? You have one slot open for what you already know, and that leaves 4 slots for new concepts to be interwoven into your knowledge. As soon as a concept is understood, that slot is free for a new concept to take its place.
